docs.lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn jury awarded $44.9 million yesterday to the family of a girl who suffered brain damage after doctors gave her mother too much anesthesia during childbirth, lawyers for the child's family said. The girl, Alexia Asteratakis, now 12, still suffers from cerebral palsy, said Thomas Moore, a lawyer for the family. He said Alexia's mother, Sarah Asteratakis, was administered an overdose of anesthesia during the delivery performed in 1986 by Dr. Louis Lissak.

headline.main: Award of $44.9 Million In Brain Damage Case

docs.abstract: Brooklyn jury awards $44.9 million to family of girl who suffered brain damage after doctors gave her mother too much anesthesia during childbirth at New York Hospital; girl, Alexia Asteratakis, is now 12 and still suffers from cerebral palsy (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Jerry Springer Show'' is the political-cultural football of the moment. Critics say the show, produced and distributed by USA Networks Studios, is beyond the pale of decent taste. Mr. Springer's defense: Elitists are out of touch, and he gives viewers a show with some meaning to them. Toplessness, fistfights and filthy language are working as a formula. Mr. Springer is beating Oprah and closing in on ''Live with Regis and Kathy Lee.''
docs.abstract: Critics say Jerry Springer Show, which often ends in free-for-all among guests, is beyond pale of decent taste, and some major figures in television are calling for Jerry Springer's removal; accusations of fakery have also been leveled; summaries of topics covered each day last week, including 'I'm in a Bizarre Love Triangle' and 'I'm Pregnant By My Brother'; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The specter of a death sentence or life in prison is gone for Amy Grossberg and Brian Peterson, now that they have pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the death of their infant son in 1996 and Delaware has dropped its charges that they murdered him. But Ms. Grossberg's plea hearing Wednesday in Wilmington, Del., was bumpier than Mr. Peterson's in March. He acknowledged criminal negligence. Her lawyers focused on her health and said that, while she felt remorse and took responsibility, she had suffered a seizure during birth caused by pregnancy-related high blood pressure she was unaware of. Prosecutors retorted that she had shown a ''chilling indifference'' to the baby's life and had caused its death through ''action or inaction.''

headline.main: April 19-25; A Teen Pleads Guilty In Baby's Death

docs.lead_paragraph: In David Blum's article ''Car Talk,'' a father warns his daughter that she may find herself having sex, either because it seems like the thing to do or because a boyfriend coerces her. He seems not even to consider that his soon-to-be teen-age daughter might have sexual longings of her own. This odd way of thinking often colors articles on teen-age sexuality and pregnancy.
docs.abstract: Letter from Norma R Fritz on Apr 5 magazine articles on mothers and motherhood (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Honor for Beverly Sills TODAY -- Beverly Sills will be honored by the American Jewish Historical Society at a dinner at the Pierre. Betty Comden and Adolph Green will perform at the black-tie event, to begin with drinks at 6:30. Tickets, $600, from (212) 245-6570, ext. 19. Rain Forest Concert MONDAY -- Sting, Elton John, James Taylor, Billy Joel, Emmy Lou Harris, Joe Cocker and Roberta Flack will be among the performers at the ninth annual Rainforest Foundation Concert at Carnegie Hall. Proceeds will benefit the foundation's programs that support ecological conservation and help guide indigenous peoples toward economic alternatives to clearing the forests. The show at 7 will be followed by supper at Tavern on the Green. Tickets, $1,750, or $450 for the concert alone, from (212) 245-6570.

Yeltsin's opponents in Russia's fractious legislature abruptly abandoned their posture of defiance and approved his nominee for Prime Minister, Sergei Kiriyenko, thus avoiding new parliamentary elections. docs.lead_paragraph: At a time when the Clinton Administration is urging the nation to invest in children's well-being -- and many states are spending their budget surpluses on early childhood initiatives -- a new study of early intervention programs for disadvantaged children has found that they can yield substantial benefits, both in better lives for the participants and lower costs for the Government. A Rand Corporation study of nine early intervention programs found that participants in most had higher long-term school achievement than similar children who did not participate. Some helped keep children out of special education, and made it less likely that they would become delinquents, spend time in an emergency room or depend on welfare.

headline.main: Early Intervention Is Shown To Benefit At-Risk Children

docs.abstract: Rand Corp study of nine early-intervention programs for disadvantaged children finds that participants in most have higher long-term school achievements than others in similar circumstances, although programs do not increase IQ scores, improve behavior or decrease odds of teen-age pregnancy or having to repeat a grade (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Although Jim Sikora has made other films, ''Bullet on a Wire,'' opening today at Anthology Film Archives (32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village), smacks of apprentice work. Amateurishly acted and clumsily directed, this spare-looking, grainy black-and-white film rests on a single intriguing idea. A middle-aged man, lonely, frustrated and clearly unstable, calls the home of a troubled teen-ager who has just undergone blood and pregnancy tests at a clinic where his sister works and informs the girl's mother that her daughter is H.I.V.-positive and pregnant. The consequences are destructive.
